title: Weyward
description: This novel tells the interconnected stories of three women, spanning centuries, who share a unique connection to nature and each other. Their narratives revolve around survival and defiance, dealing with themes of persecution and resilience.
author: Emilia Hart

title: You Have to Be Prepared to Die Before You Can Begin to Live: Ten Weeks in Birmingham That Changed America
description: Paul Kix’s gripping narrative chronicles the unsung heroes and historical figures who fought alongside Martin Luther King Jr. during a pivotal moment in American civil rights history.
author: Paul Kix

title: The Wager: A Tale of Shipwreck, Mutiny, and Murder
description: In this thrilling true story, David Grann recounts the harrowing journey of the HMS Wager, exploring themes of survival, betrayal, and the pursuit of fame.
author: David Grann

title: Happy Place
description: Emily Henry's latest novel explores the complexities of love and friendship through the lens of a second-chance romance that intertwines with family dynamics and personal growth.
author: Emily Henry

title: The Covenant of Water
description: This sweeping novel by Abraham Verghese spans generations, weaving a narrative that delves into cultural and social dynamics in India, highlighting themes of love and ambition.
author: Abraham Verghese

title: Pomegranate
description: A thought-provoking novel by Helen Elaine Lee that examines the power of fiction to reveal deeper truths about humanity and societal issues.
author: Helen Elaine Lee

title: Age of Vice
description: Deepti Kapoor's novel is a gripping saga that intertwines the lives of the wealthy and the impoverished in India, depicting a world of luxury, crime, and moral dilemmas.
author: Deepti Kapoor

title: King: A Life
description: Jonathan Eig presents a comprehensive biography of Martin Luther King Jr., detailing his extraordinary life, struggles, and contributions to the civil rights movement.
author: Jonathan Eig

title: Lady Tan's Circle of Women
description: Lisa See’s historical fiction novel centers on women's roles in medicine and society, telling the story of Lady Tan in an immersive narrative.
author: Lisa See

title: The Fraud
description: Zadie Smith’s captivating novel takes readers through the world of Victorian England, exploring themes of identity, race, and social justice through a richly woven narrative.
author: Zadie Smith

title: The Everlasting Meal Cookbook: Leftovers A-Z
description: Tamar Adler's cookbook redefines how we approach leftovers in our kitchens. With over 1,500 recipes categorized by ingredient, this book turns scraps and remnants into delicious meals, encouraging readers to rethink food waste and embrace creativity in cooking.
author: Tamar Adler

title: Bright Young Women
description: Jessica Knoll's gripping thriller is inspired by the true crimes of Ted Bundy, focusing on two women connected by tragedy. As they navigate their personal traumas, the narrative serves as both a thrilling tale and a poignant critique of the true crime genre.
author: Jessica Knoll

title: The Art Thief: A True Story of Love, Crime, and a Dangerous Obsession
description: Michael Finkel tells the thrilling story of French art thief Stéphane Breitwieser, who stole over 200 artworks across Europe. The narrative delves into the psychological motivations behind his crimes and the exhilarating chase that ensued.
author: Michael Finkel

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
description: Harper Lee's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel explores the themes of racial injustice and moral growth through the eyes of a young girl, Scout Finch, in the racially charged South during the Great Depression. As her father, Atticus Finch, defends a black man accused of raping a white woman, Scout and her brother Jem learn valuable lessons about empathy and integrity.
author: Harper Lee

title: The Catcher in the Rye
description: J.D. Salinger's novel follows the life of Holden Caulfield, a disenchanted teenager who has just been expelled from his prep school. As he wanders New York City, Holden grapples with feelings of alienation and the complexities of adulthood, ultimately seeking connection in a world he views as phony.
author: J.D. Salinger

title: Fahrenheit 451
description: Ray Bradbury's dystopian novel presents a future society where books are banned and 'firemen' burn any that are found. The story follows Guy Montag, a fireman who begins to see the value of literature and the dangers of conformity as he questions the oppressive society in which he lives.
author: Ray Bradbury

title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
description: Gabriel García Márquez's seminal work tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family in the fictional town of Macondo. Blending magical realism with historical events, the novel explores themes of solitude, love, and the cyclical nature of history.
author: Gabriel García Márquez

title: Beloved
description: Toni Morrison's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel explores the traumatic legacy of slavery through the story of Sethe, an escaped slave who is haunted by the ghost of her deceased daughter. The narrative delves into themes of memory, loss, and the struggle for identity in a post-Civil War America.
author: Toni Morrison

title: Catch-22
description: Joseph Heller's satirical novel critiques the absurdities of war through the story of Captain John Yossarian, a U.S. Army Air Forces B-25 bombardier. The term 'Catch-22' refers to the bureaucratic rule that prevents Yossarian from escaping the war, highlighting the illogical nature of military bureaucracy.
author: Joseph Heller

title: The Bell Jar
description: Sylvia Plath's semi-autobiographical novel follows Esther Greenwood, a young woman who struggles with mental illness in 1950s America. As Esther navigates societal expectations and her own sense of identity, the narrative explores themes of depression, self-discovery, and the quest for autonomy.
author: Sylvia Plath

title: The Master and Margarita
description: Mikhail Bulgakov's novel intertwines a visit by the Devil to Soviet Moscow with the story of Pontius Pilate's interactions with Jesus. The narrative explores themes of good versus evil, love, and the nature of art, offering a satirical critique of Soviet society.
author: Mikhail Bulgakov

title: The Haunting of Hill House
description: Shirley Jackson's horror novel centers on a group of individuals invited to Hill House to investigate its paranormal activity. As they experience strange occurrences, the boundaries of reality and sanity blur, leading to chilling revelations about the nature of fear and trauma.
author: Shirley Jackson

title: Slaughterhouse-Five
description: Kurt Vonnegut's novel follows the life of Billy Pilgrim, a soldier who becomes 'unstuck in time' and experiences moments from his life out of sequence. The narrative blends science fiction and anti-war sentiments as it critiques the destructiveness of war through the lens of Billy's experiences in World War II.
author: Kurt Vonnegut

title: The Great Gatsby
description: Set in the 1920s, 'The Great Gatsby' tells the story of Jay Gatsby, a mysterious millionaire, and his obsession with the beautiful Daisy Buchanan. Through the eyes of Nick Carraway, the novel explores themes of decadence, idealism, resistance to change, social upheaval, and excess, creating a portrait of the Jazz Age and the American Dream.
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

description: '1984' is a dystopian novel set in a totalitarian society governed by Big Brother. The story follows Winston Smith, who works at the Ministry of Truth, rewriting history to fit the Party's narrative. As he begins to rebel against the oppressive regime, the novel explores themes of surveillance, censorship, and individuality.
author: George Orwell

title: Neuromancer
description: Published in 1984, 'Neuromancer' is a cornerstone of the cyberpunk genre. It follows Case, a washed-up computer hacker hired by a mysterious employer to pull off the ultimate hack. The novel delves into themes of artificial intelligence, corporate power, and the nature of reality in a high-tech future.
author: William Gibson

title: The Road
description: In this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, a father and son journey through a post-apocalyptic landscape, struggling for survival amidst ash and despair. Their bond and love for each other are tested as they confront the bleakness of their world and the remnants of humanity's destruction.
author: Cormac McCarthy

title: The Handmaid's Tale
description: Margaret Atwood's dystopian novel presents a chilling future where women have been stripped of their rights. The story is told through the eyes of Offred, a Handmaid forced to bear children for the ruling class. The novel explores themes of power, gender, and the loss of autonomy.
author: Margaret Atwood

title: The Alchemist
description: This philosophical novel follows Santiago, a shepherd boy, on his journey to discover his Personal Legend. Through his travels across the desert, Santiago learns about the importance of following one's dreams and listening to one's heart, making it a timeless story about self-discovery.
author: Paulo Coelho

title: A Tale of Two Cities
description: Set against the backdrop of the French Revolution, this historical novel follows the lives of Charles Darnay and Sydney Carton, two men who love the same woman. The story explores themes of resurrection, sacrifice, and the effects of social injustice.
author: Charles Dickens

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: This classic novel follows the Joad family as they travel from Oklahoma to California during the Great Depression in search of a better life. It highlights the struggles of displaced families and the social injustices they face, making it a powerful commentary on resilience and humanity.
author: John Steinbeck

title: The Old Man and the Sea
description: This Pulitzer Prize-winning novella tells the story of an aging fisherman named Santiago who struggles with a giant marlin far out in the Gulf Stream. Through this tale of endurance and resilience, Hemingway explores themes of pride, struggle, and the relationship between man and nature.
author: Ernest Hemingway

title: Brave New World
description: A dystopian novel set in a futuristic society driven by technology and mass production. It follows Bernard Marx, who becomes disillusioned with the consumerist culture and the loss of individuality. Huxley's critique of a world without emotional depth remains relevant today.
author: Aldous Huxley

title: The Color Purple
description: This Pulitzer Prize-winning novel follows the life of Celie, an African American woman in the early 20th century American South, as she navigates the hardships of racism and sexism. The story, told through letters, celebrates resilience, sisterhood, and self-discovery.
author: Alice Walker

title: A Wrinkle in Time
description: This science fantasy novel follows Meg Murry, her brother Charles, and their friend Calvin as they travel through space and time to rescue Meg's father from an evil force. The book combines adventure with themes of love, family, and the battle between good and evil.
author: Madeleine L'Engle

title: The Joy Luck Club
description: This novel weaves together the stories of four Chinese American immigrant families in San Francisco who start a club to discuss their lives and share their cultural heritage. Through their struggles and triumphs, the novel explores themes of mother-daughter relationships and cultural identity.
author: Amy Tan

title: A Little Life
description: This profound novel follows the lives of four college friends in New York City, focusing particularly on Jude St. Francis, whose traumatic past profoundly affects his relationships. The story tackles themes of friendship, trauma, and the struggle for acceptance and love.
author: Hanya Yanagihara

title: The Night Circus
description: This enchanting novel tells the story of a magical competition between two young illusionists, Celia and Marco, who have been bound to each other by their mentors. Set in a mysterious, traveling circus that appears only at night, the narrative weaves through themes of love, rivalry, and destiny.
author: Erin Morgenstern

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
description: Set in the marshes of North Carolina, this coming-of-age mystery follows Kya Clark, the 'Marsh Girl,' as she grows up isolated from society. The novel beautifully blends themes of nature, loneliness, and love, culminating in a gripping murder investigation that unveils deep secrets.
author: Delia Owens

title: Educated
description: This memoir recounts Tara Westover's journey from growing up in a strict and abusive household in rural Idaho, with no formal education, to earning a PhD from Cambridge University. It explores themes of identity, resilience, and the transformative power of education.
author: Tara Westover

title: The Fault in Our Stars
description: This poignant novel follows the love story between two teenage cancer patients, Hazel Grace Lancaster and Augustus Waters. Their journey through illness, love, and the meaning of life explores themes of mortality, hope, and the power of love.
author: John Green

title: The Underground Railroad
description: In this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, Colson Whitehead reimagines the Underground Railroad as an actual railroad system. The story follows Cora, a young enslaved woman, as she escapes from a plantation and travels through a dangerous yet transformative journey towards freedom.
author: Colson Whitehead

title: The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo
description: This historical fiction novel follows the life of Evelyn Hugo, an aging Hollywood star who recounts her glamorous yet tumultuous life story to a young journalist. The narrative explores themes of love, ambition, and the complexities of identity in a changing world.
author: Taylor Jenkins Reid

title: Anxious People
description: This contemporary novel tells the story of a failed bank robber who takes a group of strangers hostage at an open house. As their lives intertwine, the story explores themes of empathy, connection, and the unpredictable nature of life.
author: Fredrik Backman

title: Circe
description: In this captivating retelling of the mythological figure, Circe, a lesser-known goddess, is banished to an island where she discovers her powers. The novel explores themes of femininity, power, and transformation, offering a fresh perspective on ancient mythology.
author: Madeline Miller

title: The Immortalists
description: This novel follows the lives of four siblings who visit a fortune teller in their youth, who predicts the date of their deaths. The story explores how this knowledge shapes their lives, decisions, and relationships, delving into themes of fate, family, and mortality.
author: Chloe Benjamin

title: Little Fires Everywhere
description: Set in the suburban community of Shaker Heights, Ohio, this novel explores the intertwined lives of the Richardson family and a single mother, Mia Warren, and her daughter. Themes of privilege, motherhood, and the complexities of friendship unfold in this compelling narrative.
author: Celeste Ng

title: The Light We Lost
description: This emotional love story follows Lucy and Gabe, who meet on September 11, 2001. Their lives take different paths, but the bond they share remains. The novel navigates themes of love, loss, and the impact of choices over time.
author: Jill Santopolo

title: Normal People
description: This novel tells the story of Connell and Marianne, two high school students in Ireland whose lives become intertwined as they navigate their complex relationship from adolescence into adulthood. The book addresses themes of love, friendship, and social class.
author: Sally Rooney

title: The Overstory
description: A sweeping narrative that intertwines the lives of nine characters and their connection to trees, this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel examines the relationship between humanity and nature. Each character's story converges in a powerful message about environmental conservation.
author: Richard Powers

title: The Kite Runner
description: Set against the backdrop of a changing Afghanistan, this novel follows the story of Amir, who seeks redemption for betraying his childhood friend Hassan. The book explores themes of friendship, guilt, and the complex relationship between fathers and sons.
author: Khaled Hosseini

title: Before the Fall
description: This gripping thriller centers on the aftermath of a plane crash off the coast of Martha's Vineyard. The story follows the investigation into the crash and the secrets of its passengers, exploring themes of fate, privilege, and the consequences of choices.
author: Noah Hawley

title: The Girl on the Train
description: This psychological thriller follows Rachel, an alcoholic woman who becomes entangled in a missing person investigation. The narrative unfolds through multiple perspectives, revealing secrets and lies that keep readers on the edge of their seats.
author: Paula Hawkins

title: The Guest List
description: Set on a remote Irish island, this suspenseful novel revolves around a wedding celebration that turns deadly. The story alternates between different characters' perspectives, unveiling secrets and tensions that lead to murder, all while exploring themes of loyalty and betrayal.
author: Lucy Foley

title: The Vanishing Half
description: This multigenerational saga follows the lives of twin sisters who choose to live in very different racial identities. The novel explores themes of identity, family, and the impact of choices across generations, ultimately raising questions about race and belonging.
author: Brit Bennett

title: The Silent Patient
description: This psychological thriller centers around Alicia Berenson, a woman who inexplicably shoots her husband and then stops speaking. As a psychotherapist tries to unravel her silence, dark secrets emerge, leading to a shocking conclusion that questions the nature of truth.
author: Alex Michaelides

title: The Nightingale
description: Set during World War II in France, this novel follows the lives of two sisters, Vianne and Isabelle, who each navigate the war's dangers in their own way. The story highlights themes of courage, survival, and the impact of war on women.
author: Kristin Hannah

title: Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine
description: This quirky novel follows Eleanor Oliphant, a socially awkward woman with a dark past. As she develops a friendship with a coworker, her life begins to change. The story addresses themes of loneliness, mental health, and the importance of human connection.
author: Gail Honeyman

title: Station Eleven
description: This dystopian novel explores the aftermath of a pandemic that wipes out most of humanity. The narrative follows a traveling theater troupe as they navigate a world where civilization has collapsed. Themes of art, memory, and survival are woven throughout the story.
author: Emily St. John Mandel

title: The Goldfinch
description: This Pulitzer Prize-winning novel follows Theo Decker, a young boy whose life changes dramatically after surviving a terrorist attack in a museum that kills his mother. The story explores themes of loss, art, and the struggle for identity over the years.
author: Donna Tartt

title: Big Little Lies
description: This darkly comedic novel explores the lives of three women in a wealthy Australian suburb. As their secrets unravel, the narrative builds to a shocking event at a school trivia night, tackling themes of domestic violence, friendship, and motherhood.
author: Liane Moriarty

title: The Seven Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle
description: In this unique murder mystery, Aiden Bishop must relive the same day repeatedly, inhabiting different bodies, to solve the murder of Evelyn Hardcastle. The complex narrative blends elements of time travel and classic whodunit storytelling.
author: Stuart Turton

title: The Giver of Stars
description: This historical novel tells the story of a group of women in Depression-era Kentucky who become part of the Pack Horse Library Project, delivering books to rural communities. Their journey emphasizes the power of literature and friendship in the face of adversity.
author: Jojo Moyes

title: The Testaments
description: Set 15 years after 'The Handmaid’s Tale,' this sequel unfolds in the dystopian society of Gilead, exploring themes of power and resistance through the eyes of three female characters. The novel provides a gripping continuation of Atwood’s original narrative.
author: Margaret Atwood

title: A Man Called Ove
description: This heartwarming novel centers around Ove, a grumpy yet lovable man whose life changes when a lively family moves in next door. Through unlikely friendships, the story explores themes of love, loss, and the impact one life can have on another.
author: Fredrik Backman

title: The Song of Achilles
description: This retelling of the Iliad explores the relationship between Achilles and Patroclus, weaving themes of love, honor, and the cost of war into a poignant narrative. It brings a fresh perspective to the well-known story of the Trojan War.
author: Madeline Miller

title: An American Marriage
description: This novel examines the complexities of love and marriage through the lens of a wrongful conviction. As Celestial and Roy navigate their relationship while Roy is imprisoned, the story tackles themes of race, justice, and the impact of societal expectations.
author: Tayari Jones

title: The Water Dancer
description: This novel combines historical fiction with magical realism, following Hiram Walker, a young enslaved man with a mysterious power. Set against the backdrop of the Underground Railroad, the story explores themes of memory, family, and the quest for freedom.
author: Ta-Nehisi Coates

title: Homegoing
description: This powerful novel traces the lineage of two half-sisters, Effia and Esi, across centuries and continents, exploring the impact of slavery on their descendants. The narrative reveals how history shapes individual identities and the ongoing effects of colonialism.
author: Yaa Gyasi

title: Pachinko
description: This sweeping historical novel follows four generations of a Korean family living in Japan, dealing with issues of identity, belonging, and the immigrant experience. The narrative spans decades and highlights the resilience of the human spirit amidst adversity.
author: Min Jin Lee

title: The Dutch House
description: This novel follows siblings Danny and Maeve as they navigate their lives in the shadow of their childhood home, the Dutch House. The story explores themes of family, inheritance, and the lasting impact of the past on the present.
author: Ann Patchett

title: The Tattooist of Auschwitz
description: Based on a true story, this historical novel follows Lale Sokolov, who is tasked with tattooing the identification numbers of prisoners in Auschwitz. Amidst the horror of the concentration camp, Lale finds love and hope, illustrating the resilience of the human spirit.
author: Heather Morris

title: Before the Coffee Gets Cold
description: Set in a Japanese cafe, this heartwarming novel follows four characters who wish to travel back in time. The story reveals their regrets and desires, emphasizing the importance of living in the moment and the power of human connection.
author: Toshikazu Kawaguchi

title: The Book Thief
description: Set in Nazi Germany, this novel follows a young girl named Liesel who finds solace in stealing books and sharing them with others. The story, narrated by Death, explores the power of words and the impact of war on ordinary lives.
author: Markus Zusak
